etymology.description: 䇂(䇂) (chisel) + 見(見) (jiàn, 'kneeling person with a huge eye') -> depicted punishment -> 東 corrupted over time -> modern phonetic 立(立) (lì, 'stand') + semantic 里(里) (lǐ, 'village')
etymology.interpretation: Originally depicting a cruel punishment involving eye gouging, the character evolved to incorporate 東 as a phonetic element, eventually corrupting to 立, with the bottom 里 reflecting the phonetic development similar to the character 重. Despite its origin, 童(tóng) is now associated with 'child' or 'boy' in modern usage.

parts.english: kneeling person with a huge eye

examples.chinese: 公园里的小童正在追逐蝴蝶(公園裡的小童正在追逐蝴蝶)。
examples.pinyin: Gōngyuán lǐ de xiǎo tóng zhèngzài zhuīzhú húdié.
examples.english: The little child in the park is chasing butterflies.

examples.chinese: 小童在院子里玩耍(小童在院子裡玩耍)，露出灿烂笑容(露出燦爛笑容)。
examples.pinyin: Xiǎo tóng zài yuànzi lǐ wánshuǎ, lùchū cànlàn xiàoróng.
examples.english: The child is playing in the yard and showing a bright smile.
